title: Transform CIAA Into a Truly Independent Anti-Corruption Force
description: Transform Nepal's anti-corruption commission into a powerful, independent body that can actually investigate and prosecute corruption cases without political interference.

problem.long: Nepal's Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA), though constitutionally established under Articles 238 and 239 of the Constitution (2015) and governed by the CIAA Act 2048 (1991) and its Rules 2049, remains largely ineffective despite having strong legal powers on paper. Key issues include: Politicised leadership where the Chief Commissioner and other member Commissioners are politically appointed; Lack of operational independence where the CIAA depends on the Ministry of Finance for its budget; Narrowed jurisdiction where the 2015 Constitution removed its authority to investigate 'improper conduct'; and Weak institutional capacity where Investigation and prosecution units are understaffed, siloed, and lack advanced forensic and digital tools.

phases.title: Immediate Statutory Reforms
items: Integrated investigation—prosecution teams: Build mixed teams where legal experts work alongside investigators
Collaboration with the Office of the Attorney General: Second prosecutors to the CIAA until internal capacity developed
Specialised training: Mandatory 6—7 month intensive training for new investigation and prosecution staff
Adequate staffing: Significantly expand investigators, forensic auditors, digital forensics specialists, and prosecutors
Performance safeguards: Enforce strict code of conduct, require minimum two-year service terms

phases.title: Constitutional Reforms
items: Constitutional budget allocation: Independent funding line, not dependent on Finance Ministry (Article 238-239 amendment)
Merit-based appointments: Chief Commissioner and Commissioners selected through competitive examination by independent panel
Fixed tenure protection: Introduce a 5—8 year fixed term tenure to prevent capture while avoiding lifetime appointments
Jurisdiction over corruption and improper conduct: Amending Article 239 and extending CIAA's jurisdiction
Diverse expertise: Recruit Commissioners from varied technical backgrounds

long.details: CPIB achieved 98% conviction rate through complete independence, direct prosecution powers, and asset recovery authority
long.impact: Critical sequencing: Singapore first strengthened powers through legislation (1952), then achieved full independence through constitutional protection (1965)

long.details: ICAC reformed gradually: 1974 initial legislation gave prosecution powers, 1997 constitutional entrenchment secured independence
long.impact: Went from investigating 2,300 cases annually to virtually eliminating government corruption within a decade

long.details: KPK demonstrates phased approach: 2002 law created prosecution authority, 2004 constitutional amendment secured independence
long.impact: 77% conviction rate with major high-level prosecutions including ministers and governors
